coredata.dc:description: The seabed is one of the key ecological interfaces on the planet, exerting a major influence on global biogeochemical cycles. Biological processes such as bioturbation - the reworking of sediment by activities of benthic fauna - are key in mediating fluxes of nutrients, carbon, and oxygen from the water column into the sediment. To date, most research on bioturbation has focused on the role of sediment-dwelling invertebrates with the contribution of other and often larger organisms such as fish largely overlooked. Here, we highlight the significant and underappreciated role of fish as bioturbators in benthic ecosystems and present the first systematic approach to assess fish bioturbation impact on the seabed based on ecological traits known to influence sediment reworking. We show that 185 fish species across 62 families are bioturbators on the UK continental shelf, exhibiting a range of bioturbation modes, for example through burrowing, feeding, and nesting activities. Our analysis demonstrates that many important bioturbators are highly vulnerable to loss and extinction. Out of the 185 fish species bioturbating on the UK shelf, 120 are commercially exploited, with some of the most significant bioturbators among the most highly commercially fished. Our findings highlight the risk of alteration of benthic ecosystem processes resulting from the potential removal of these key bioturbators. This novel framework provides a simple yet powerful tool for assessing fish contributions to benthic ecosystem functioning and represents a first step towards incorporating fish bioturbation into future seabed management decisions.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Characteristics and indicative examples of the five bioturbation modes developed for fish species known to interact with the seafloor in UK shelf waters.

Summary of the 185 bioturbating fish species occurring in UK shelf seas across the five bioturbation modes for fish. Numbers within the bar denote the total number of species in that mode, with percentages in brackets. Mean (± standard error) bioturbation scores for species within each bioturbation mode are shown in the bar plot on the right.

Bioturbation impact scores across the 62 bioturbating fish families occurring in UK shelf seas. (A) Density estimates of bioturbation impact scores for 24 families containing three or more species. (B) Bioturbation impact scores for the remaining 38 families, where grey points depict families with only a single species, and black points show mean bioturbation score and standard error for families with two species. Where no error bars are visible, both species within the family had the same bioturbation impact score.

Principal Component Analysis (PCA) biplot showing the relationship between the three metrics of bioturbation: bioturbation mode, frequency, and body size. Data points are coloured by bioturbation score, and jittering was applied to enable the visualisation of overlapping species. PCA loadings of the three metrics of bioturbation are represented by the arrows.

Vulnerability of fish bioturbators to loss and extinction. (A) Fish bioturbation impact scores across different levels of commercial fisheries exploitation (NC – not commercial, MC – minor commercial, C – commercial, HC – highly commercial) (B) Fish bioturbation impact score increases with vulnerability to fishing, assessed by FishBase's fishing vulnerability index (regression line ± standard error). (C) Fish bioturbation impact scores (mean ± standard error) across the seven IUCN categories (NE - not evaluated, DD – data deficient, LC – least concern, NT – near threatened, VU – vulnerable, EN – endangered, CR – critically endangered), with increasing risk moving from left to right and the number of fish species in each threat level given at the top. (D) Boxplots with the mean (◊) and median (|) fish bioturbation impact score across the three IUCN threat levels, with raw data plotted as points and distributions shown by half-violins.
Scoring criteria for the three metrics used to compute bioturbation impact scores for fish: bioturbation mode, body size, and bioturbation frequency.

head.ce:title: A functional assessment of fish as bioturbators and their vulnerability to local extinction

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The seabed is one of the key ecological interfaces on the planet, exerting a major influence on global biogeochemical cycles. Biological processes such as bioturbation - the reworking of sediment by activities of benthic fauna - are key in mediating fluxes of nutrients, carbon, and oxygen from the water column into the sediment. To date, most research on bioturbation has focused on the role of sediment-dwelling invertebrates with the contribution of other and often larger organisms such as fish largely overlooked. Here, we highlight the significant and underappreciated role of fish as bioturbators in benthic ecosystems and present the first systematic approach to assess fish bioturbation impact on the seabed based on ecological traits known to influence sediment reworking. We show that 185 fish species across 62 families are bioturbators on the UK continental shelf, exhibiting a range of bioturbation modes, for example through burrowing, feeding, and nesting activities. Our analysis demonstrates that many important bioturbators are highly vulnerable to loss and extinction. Out of the 185 fish species bioturbating on the UK shelf, 120 are commercially exploited, with some of the most significant bioturbators among the most highly commercially fished. Our findings highlight the risk of alteration of benthic ecosystem processes resulting from the potential removal of these key bioturbators. This novel framework provides a simple yet powerful tool for assessing fish contributions to benthic ecosystem functioning and represents a first step towards incorporating fish bioturbation into future seabed management decisions.

ce:section.ce:para: Globally, marine sediments extend over an area of 360 million km2 (Eakins and Sharman, 2007), play vital functional roles in major ecological processes and global biogeochemical cycles (Middelburg, 2018; Snelgrove et al., 2018), and are increasingly recognised as significant organic carbon stores (Atwood et al., 2020). For example, a recent report estimated that across the UK's seas, 240 Mt of organic carbon are stored in the top 10 cm of sediment (Burrows et al., 2024). Microbial processing of organic carbon in marine sediments is key in regulating global levels of carbon dioxide, oxygen, and methane (Arndt et al., 2013; Burdige, 2007), which is in turn mediated by the activities of benthic fauna (Meysman et al., 2006; Solan et al., 2004).

Bioturbation or the biogenic modification of the sediment matrix by animal activity has been a key ecological process on the seabed since the Cambrian (Bottjer et al., 2000; Meysman et al., 2006; Thayer, 1979). The global estimate (25–75 % quantiles) of the volume of bioturbated sediment is 13,700 to 32,500 km3 (Zhang et al., 2024), but the relative contribution of different phyla to this volume is not known. Whilst we have a good mechanistic understanding of invertebrate-based bioturbation (Kristensen et al., 2012; Meysman et al., 2006), the contribution of fish is poorly constrained and has received much less attention. Fish are the most biodiverse group of vertebrates on Earth and are globally abundant, with 35,800 species described in FishBase (Froese and Pauly, 2024). Fish are ubiquitous throughout the global ocean, occurring across all latitudes and down to depths of over 8000 m (Jamieson et al., 2023). Many described marine fish species interact with the seabed, for example by foraging, seeking shelter, and building nests to lay eggs (Barber et al., 2001; D'Andrea et al., 2004; Shelton, 1978; Suchanek and Colin, 1986). Such activities are likely to make substantive contributions to sediment reworking and as such need to be better quantified.

The role of fish as bioturbators has been recognised across geological timescales, with Agnath fish being important bioturbators as early as the Cambrian (Thayer, 1979). Work on tropical fish communities in the 1980s acknowledged the likely significant effects of fish bioturbation but noted that conclusive bioturbation rates for fish were lacking (Suchanek and Colin, 1986). More recent studies have attempted to quantify fish bioturbation, with most research focused on shallow coastal ecosystems such as mangroves, saltmarshes, and intertidal sand flats (Sarker et al., 2021). Though several groups of fish bioturbate, with some such as gobies (Myers et al., 2019) and tilefish (Able et al., 1982) forming extensive burrow systems, there has been a strong research bias towards skates and rays. These elasmobranchs create large feeding pits, which can have both biotic and abiotic effects on the benthic ecosystem to create a significant impact on sediment turnover (D'Andrea et al., 2004; Flowers et al., 2021; Grew et al., 2024; Nauta et al., 2024; O'Shea et al., 2012; Takeuchi and Tamaki, 2014; Thrush et al., 1991). Estimates of their bioturbation rates range from 0.167 m3 m−2 yr−1 by stingrays (Pastinachus atrus, Himantura spp. Taeniura lymma and Urogymnus asperrimus) in Australia (O'Shea et al., 2012) to 0.279 m3 m−2 yr−1 by the pearl whipray (Fontitrygon margaritella) in Guinea-Bissau (Nauta et al., 2024) and up to 1.01 m3 m−2 yr−1 by Myliobatis californica and Urobatis halleri in the Gulf of California (Myrick and Flessa, 1996). This degree of bioturbation is likely to be of disproportionate influence at local spatial and temporal scales, considering that the background estimate (25–75 % quantiles) of bioturbation intensity for the world's continental shelves (<200 m depth) is 0.61–18.8 cm2 yr−1 and the mixed depth is 3.6–11.0 cm (Solan et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2024). Factors that influence bioturbation rates among different species are differences in their shape, size, and density, the effects of local environmental conditions (Sanders et al., 2025; Wohlgemuth et al., 2017), and differences in methodologies between studies (Flowers et al., 2021).

It is widely recognised that fish can have significant effects on sediment biogeochemistry and nutrient cycling (Colina et al., 2021; Goeke et al., 2025; McIntyre et al., 2007; Oliveira Junior et al., 2019; Persson and Svensson, 2006; Vanni, 2002). Though these effects have largely been studied in freshwater environments, the mechanistic basis of fish-sediment interaction is transferable to marine systems. Fish affect nutrient dynamics directly and indirectly through excretion and bioturbation (Adámek and Maršálek, 2013; Breukelaar et al., 1994; Goeke et al., 2025; Vanni, 2002). The resuspension of sediment caused by fish bioturbation can lead to increased water turbidity and nutrient loading in the water column, promoting phytoplankton growth, which in turn facilitates photosynthesis and the drawdown of carbon dioxide (Colina et al., 2021; Rahman, 2015). Benthivorous fish bioturbation is sometimes used as a management strategy in aquaculture ponds to boost phyto- and zooplankton availability to planktivorous fish (Rahman, 2015). Since fish species vary widely in their rates of excreting nitrogen relative to phosphorus, changes in community composition can have far-reaching effects on nutrient cycling and primary productivity (McIntyre et al., 2007; Vanni, 2002). Changes in fish community composition brought about by fishing and other pressures, potentially leading to local extinctions of certain important nutrient-cycling fish species, can therefore have widespread ecosystem implications (McIntyre et al., 2007).

Few studies have investigated in situ the effects of fish bioturbation on biogeochemical cycles. Research conducted in Canada estimated that sediment resuspension of sediment by groundfish could reduce organic carbon sequestration by up to 40 % (Yahel et al., 2008), whilst others have reported increased organic matter and organic carbon concentrations within ray feeding pits (D'Andrea et al., 2002; Thrush et al., 1991; VanBlaricom, 1982). Since fish bioturbation evidently has far-reaching and complex impacts on nutrient cycling at the sediment-water interface in both freshwater and marine systems, we need to fully determine the fish contributions to bioturbation and expand research efforts to more groups than are currently considered.

Here, we highlight the significant and underappreciated role of fish as bioturbators. Building on accepted bioturbation classifications for invertebrate bioturbation (Francois et al., 1997; Gerino et al., 2003; Kristensen et al., 2012; Solan et al., 2004), we develop a new classification for fish and present a universal framework for the functional assessment of their bioturbation impact. Given that fish diversity is under threat globally from a multitude of pressures including overexploitation, climate change, invasive species, pollution, and habitat degradation (Arthington et al., 2016; Dulvy et al., 2021; Jackson et al., 2001; Pauly et al., 1998), understanding how these pressures influence the important contributions fish bioturbation makes to ecosystem properties that underscore the provision of services and benefits to society is crucial.

Globally, continental shelves (shallow coastal seas <200 m in depth) support diverse fish assemblages whilst simultaneously being relatively accessible to research efforts. Here we use the UK shelf seas as a case study since functional traits of most species are well known. For the region, our study will present the first species list of fish that interact with the UK shelf's seabed and their functional classification into bioturbation modes. Though others have attempted to group fish (or megafauna more widely) based on their interactions with the sediment (e.g. McIntyre et al., 2007; Suchanek and Colin, 1986; Vallim et al., 2024), we provide to our knowledge the first systematic approach for the functional assessment of fish bioturbation.

To identify the fish species that interact with the seabed, we first examined a published dataset of species in the North Sea and Celtic Biscay Shelf Large Marine Ecosystems and from these gathered their ecological trait information (Beukhof et al., 2019). This resulted in a list of 364 species (Fig. S1). Additionally, the search function on FishBase (Froese and Pauly, 2024) was used to compile a list of all marine fishes reported in the UK which generated 355 species (Fig. S1). After merging the two datasets and removing duplicates, 288 species remained (Fig. S1). To determine whether each interacts with the seabed, and if so how, we first gained information from examining the species page of the web version of FishBase (Froese and Pauly, 2024), under the headings ‘Biology’ and ‘Life cycle and mating behaviour’. Where FishBase contained insufficient information for a species, we consulted the “Key to the Fishes of Northern Europe” (Wheeler, 1978) and The Marine Life Information Network, MarLIN (MBA, 2024). If thereafter information was still insufficient; the primary literature was consulted.

All species with no available information to suggest that they interact with the seabed were excluded from further analysis. The final number of species considered to interact with seabed sediments on the UK shelf was n = 185 (Fig. S1).

We used widely accepted functional group classifications for invertebrates (Francois et al., 1997; Gerino et al., 2003; Kristensen et al., 2012; Solan et al., 2004), as well as previous groupings of fish into disturbance modes (Suchanek and Colin, 1986), to develop new universal bioturbation modes for fish. Although some fish species can certainly be classified as surficial modifiers, regenerators, or biodiffusors according to the invertebrate scheme, we believe that modification of these categories is necessary to better encompass the plethora of fish interactions with the seabed, which differ significantly from those of invertebrates. Early work on the bioturbation of tropical lagoon sediments (Suchanek and Colin, 1986), grouped fish species into seven disturbance modes based on their interactions with the sediment. Here, we refine and condense these categories into five novel bioturbation modes for fish: species that filter the uppermost layers of sediment for food, the sediment sifters; species that create wide pits to access food or shelter, the lateral excavators; species that actively modify the surface of the seabed to create nests, the nest-builders; species that dig vertically into the sediment to access prey or shelter, the vertical excavators; and species who create and maintain burrows, the burrowers (Fig. 1 ). We used the information on species’ interactions with the seabed recorded during data compilation to group the 185 fish species found to interact with the seabed on the UK shelf into these five bioturbation modes (Table S1).

Adapting the index of bioturbation potential developed for invertebrates by Solan et al. (2004) that scores the mode of sediment reworking and mobility of bioturbating taxa, we calculated fish maximum potential bioturbation impact (BI) on sediment reworking using the following equation:
(1)
B I = B M ∗ B S ∗ B F

This metric combines three traits that influence sediment bioturbation: (i) the method of reworking the sediment (bioturbation mode, BM), (ii) body size (BS, weight in grams), and (iii) the frequency of interaction with the sediment (bioturbation frequency, BF). Each metric was scored on a categorical scale from 1 to 5, reflecting the increasing impact on sediment turnover, though it should be noted that these numbers are arbitrary and used as a means to separate contribution, i.e. a score of 5 does not reflect a five-fold increase in contribution (Table 1 ).

Since fish bioturbation behaviour scales with body size, we use fish body mass as a proxy for the spatial extent of disturbance to the seabed. Fish body mass was calculated for each species using the allometric length-weight relationship, expressing weight (W, in g) as a function of length (L, in cm):
(2)
W = a
L b
where a and b are published Bayesian species-specific parameters taken from FishBase (Froese and Pauly, 2024). Maximum observed length (Lmax) was used in body mass calculations, a parameter available on FishBase for most species we investigated. To account for the large variation in body mass values, each species was assigned to a log10 body size class from very small to very large (Table 1).

Bioturbation frequency was determined by consulting available information on species' behaviour on interactions with the seabed. Species seabed interactions were classed as ‘very frequent’, i.e. interacting with the seabed near-continuously (e.g. species living in or on the seabed with a fully benthic diet); ‘frequent’, interact with seabed regularly but not continuously (e.g. species with mostly benthic diet); ‘occasional’, periodically interact with the seabed (e.g. species that mainly feed pelagically); ‘rarely’: infrequent interaction with the seabed is localised and linked to specific behaviours (e.g. species nesting on seabed or opportunistic feeders); and ‘very rarely/unknown’, species that almost never interact with the seabed or for which limited evidence is available (e.g. primarily pelagic species) (Table 1).

Human activities are increasingly putting marine species under pressure, to the extent that species may be depleted and possibly driven to local and ultimately global extinction (del Monte-Luna et al., 2023; Dulvy et al., 2003; Roberts and Hawkins, 1999). To explore the relationship between fish bioturbation and commercial fisheries exploitation, we extracted information regarding the level of commercial exploitation from the species page of the web version of FishBase (Froese and Pauly, 2024), under the heading ‘Human uses’. Additionally, we used the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List of Threatened Species (IUCN, 2024) and FishBase's fishing vulnerability index (Froese and Pauly, 2024) to assess the relationship between fish bioturbation potential and vulnerability to loss and extinction.

The IUCN Red List is the most widely recognised method for assessing species’ extinction risk and incorporates population size and population decline/increase, geographic range, and extinction probability analyses (IUCN, 2024; Mace et al., 2008). Species are categorised as extinct (EX), extinct in the wild (EW), critically endangered (CR), endangered (EN), vulnerable (VU), near threatened (NT), least concern (LC), data deficient (DD), and not evaluated (NE). Species in the CR, EN, and VU categories are considered threatened (Mace et al., 2008). While the IUCN Red List assessment is highly comprehensive, it requires relatively detailed data on population dynamics, which are often lacking for marine species (Kaplan et al., 2014). Therefore, many marine fish species have not been evaluated or been classed as data deficient.

FishBase's vulnerability index is less sensitive to a lack of data than the IUCN Red List (Kaplan et al., 2014; Strona, 2014), and employs a method which estimates intrinsic vulnerability by integrating life history and ecological characteristics, such as body length, growth rate, life span, age at maturity, and trophic level (Cheung et al., 2005; Strona, 2014). FishBase's fishing vulnerability index is continuous, ranging from very low to very high vulnerability (0–100). For full details of how the index is computed readers are referred to Cheung et al. (2005).

Following the FishBase approach, large-bodied fish with a slow growth rate, long life span, and late reproduction tend to be the most vulnerable, whilst species with a limited geographic range are more vulnerable under the IUCN assessment (Strona, 2014). Here we use both assessment methods to ensure a complementary approach in investigating the relationship between fish bioturbation and vulnerability.

We conducted a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to explore the relationships between the three bioturbation metrics (bioturbation mode, frequency, and body size) and bioturbation impact score, using the PCA function from the FactoMineR package in R (version 4.2.1) (Lê et al., 2008). Results of the PCA were visualised using the factoextra package (Kassambara and Mundt, 2020). We used a linear regression model to assess the relationship between bioturbation score (response variable) and fishing vulnerability index (predictor variable). Model assumptions, including normality of residuals and homoscedasticity, were assessed using diagnostic plots. We grouped species into three threat levels based on the IUCN Red List categories: threatened (VU, EN, CR), non-threatened (LC, NT), and threat unknown (NE, DD). To assess differences in bioturbation impact score between these different threat levels and between different levels of commercial fisheries exploitation, we used a Kruskall-Wallis test with a post hoc Dunn's test for pairwise comparisons, with Bonferroni correction applied to adjust for multiple comparisons. All data analyses and visualisations were carried out in R under version 4.2.1 (R Core Team, 2024). The tidyverse collection of R packages was used for data manipulation and visualisation (Wickham et al., 2019). Multi-panel figures were created using the cowplot package (Wilke, 2024).

We observed substantial differences in the range of bioturbation impact scores across 62 families of fish occurring in UK shelf seas (Fig. 3). Many species within the same family had similar bioturbation impacts, evidenced by families such as the Rajidae (skates) and Labridae (wrasses), which exhibited normal distributions of bioturbation behaviour (Fig. 3A). The width of those distributions is an indication of intragroup variation in contribution to bioturbation behaviour. Other families were more widely spread across the spectrum of bioturbation impact, showing bimodal, trimodal, or other shaped distributions, which might suggest context dependency or differences caused by other factors such as size or lifestyle changes with age (Fig. 3A). The overlap in distributions between disparate groups such as Rajidae and Sparidae reflects the importance of a species’ functional contribution to bioturbation over its taxonomic position (Fig. 3A). Many families contained only a single species of bioturbating fish, with families at the two extremes of bioturbation impact such as the Myxinidae and Gobiesocidae representing potentially unique functional bioturbation roles (Fig. 3B).

PCA of the three metrics of bioturbation impact revealed that bioturbation frequency and body size are characterised by higher PC1 values, while bioturbation mode is characterised by higher PC2 values (Fig. 4 ). All three metrics are associated with higher bioturbation scores, being clustered in the top right corner of the biplot (Fig. 4). Bioturbation mode explains a larger proportion of the variance along the principal components compared to the other two metrics, indicated by its longer arrow in the biplot (Fig. 4). The clustering of data points suggests that species with similar trait values share corresponding functional roles in terms of bioturbation (Fig. 4).

Out of the 185 species of fish bioturbating on the UK shelf, 120 (64 %) are commercially exploited (Fig. 5 A). Fisheries exploitation status had a significant effect on fish bioturbation impact score (Kruskall-Wallis test: χ2 (3) = 12.3, p < 0.01; Fig. 5A). While species with commercial (mean ± SE = 34.6 ± 3.04, n = 53) and minor commercial (mean ± SE = 34.7 ± 3.19, n = 51) exploitation status exhibited similar bioturbation impact scores to unexploited species (mean ± SE = 31.3 ± 3.67, n = 39), highly commercial species had significantly higher scores (mean ± SE = 55.3 ± 5.43, n = 16, p < 0.01) (Fig. 5A). There was a significant positive relationship between bioturbation impact score and FishBase's fishing vulnerability index (LM: b ± S.E. = 0.459 ± 0.0652, t(183) = 7.004, p < 0.001, Fig. 5A). However, fishing vulnerability index explains only a relatively small proportion of the variation in bioturbation impact score (Adjusted R2 = 0.21). Out of the 185 fish species bioturbating on the UK shelf, 12 % were classed as threatened, 63 % as non-threatened, and for 25 % of species their level of threat was unknown (Fig. 5B). There was a significant difference in fish bioturbation impact scores between extinction threat levels (Kruskall-Wallis test: χ2 (2) = 21.9, p < 0.001; Fig. 5C). Threatened species exhibit significantly higher bioturbation impact scores (mean ± SE = 53.7 ± 4.55, n = 23) than non-threatened species (mean ± SE = 29.1 ± 1.9, n = 116, p < 0.001), and species with unknown threat levels (mean ± SE = 37.7 ± 3.49, n = 46, p < 0.01) (Fig. 5C). There was a marginal difference in bioturbation impact scores between non-threatened species and those whose level of threat was unknown (p = 0.07) (Fig. 5C).

Here, we highlight the significant and often underappreciated role of fish as bioturbators. We show that fish bioturbation on the UK shelf is ubiquitous and not limited to only a few groups. Our classification of fish into bioturbation modes and index to assess potential bioturbation impact provide novel tools urgently needed to put fish bioturbation on the map and to aid its inclusion into protection and management decisions. Our analysis demonstrates that several important bioturbators are commercially highly exploited species, emphasising the potential threat to the loss of benthic ecosystem functioning by reducing or removing those species.

In line with broader biodiversity research, which tends to exhibit a taxonomic bias towards more charismatic species (Troudet et al., 2017), studies on fish bioturbation to date have largely focused on skates and rays (e.g. Nauta et al., 2024; O'Shea et al., 2012; Takeuchi and Tamaki, 2014). Here we found that although skates and rays in UK shelf seas can have a significant bioturbation impact, they are not among the top players. For example, species from the families Anarhichadidae (wolffishes), Triakidae (houndsharks), and Sparidae (seabreams and porgies) were higher ranked bioturbators than skates and rays (Fig. 3). Two of the top bioturbators we identified on the UK shelf were the Atlantic wolffish, Anarhichas lupus, a large-bodied demersal fish that primarily interacts with the seabed through feeding, and the Atlantic hagfish, Myxine glutinosa, an eel-shaped jawless fish that constructs extensive burrow systems in muddy sediments. The latter can reach lengths of up to 95 cm and often occurs in high densities (e.g. up to 500,000 individuals per square kilometre in the Gulf of Maine), exerting a strong influence on sediment turnover and nutrient cycling through their burrowing and feeding activities (Foss, 1968; Martini et al., 1997; Martini, 1998; Shelton, 1978). While M. glutinosa is currently of no interest to commercial fisheries, A. lupus numbers have been declining in the North Sea, primarily from being caught as bycatch (Bluemel et al., 2022), with potential consequences for benthic ecosystem functioning associated with the decrease of an important bioturbator (here ranked 2nd alongside eight other species out of 185 bioturbating species). While we have highlighted species with high per capita bioturbation effects, we need a better understanding of which species carry out the bulk of bioturbation by linking to local abundance. Species' contributions to sediment reworking may also be dependent on geographic and seasonal context as has been demonstrated for sediment-dwelling invertebrates (Sanders et al., 2025), and requires further research in the context of fish bioturbation.

Sediment reworking by fish tends to be patchier than that done by invertebrate macrofauna, often resulting in spatially clustered patterns of bioturbation (Grew et al., 2024; Takeuchi and Tamaki, 2014). This is because fish bioturbation, which primarily occurs during foraging, often depends on the distribution and density of prey in sediment (Takeuchi and Tamaki, 2014), whilst infaunal bioturbation, though mediated by habitat heterogeneity and resource distribution (Bulling et al., 2008; Godbold et al., 2011; Levinton and Kelaher, 2004), tends to be near-continuous and more evenly distributed (Vallim et al., 2024). Fish have the potential to individually and collectively disturb larger areas of sediment than invertebrates, mainly owing to their larger size and mobility. For example, an individual Australian whipray (Himantura australis) can excavate 200 tonnes of sediment in a single year (Crook et al., 2022), while a population of stingrays were estimated to rework up to 42 % of sediments in an intertidal habitat of 42,000 m2 each year (O'Shea et al., 2012).

Quantifying the impacts of fish bioturbation on benthic ecosystem functioning and biogeochemical cycles is complicated by the web of interactions between fish and infaunal invertebrate communities. Since fish bioturbation is often the result of fish predation on infaunal invertebrates, their roles are not simply additive to invertebrate bioturbation. Fish predation may be lethal or sublethal, the latter for example resulting from the cropping of arms of ophiuroids (Lawrence and Vasquez, 1996; Pape-Lindstrom et al., 1997). Low levels of predation are likely to stimulate bioturbation by increasing turnover, but excessive predation will increase the effect of fish on the system (direct and indirect contribution to bioturbation as a whole). The reduction or removal of specific invertebrates, or more generally a large number, may open an opportunity for others to colonise and potentially compensate, which may fundamentally alter the biodiversity-function relationship in terms of bioturbation (Thomsen et al., 2017, 2019). The temporary increase in organic matter and organic carbon concentrations observed in some studies on ray feeding pits may have been an effect of rapid colonisation by infauna (D'Andrea et al., 2002; Thrush et al., 1991; VanBlaricom, 1982). Conversely, bioturbation by burrowing crabs facilitates fish predation on invertebrates in estuaries (Martinetto et al., 2005). In coastal vegetated ecosystems, predator populations indirectly help protect blue carbon stocks by controlling the number of herbivores, thereby preventing the destruction of vegetation and removal of stored carbon (Atwood et al., 2015). Further research into the interactions between fish and invertebrates is needed to better understand the outcomes on overall ecosystem functioning.

This analysis has highlighted that some of the most important fish bioturbators are commercially highly exploited and most at risk from reduction and local extinction (Fig. 5). This is illustrated by two independent vulnerability assessment methods, highlighting the significant threat to the alteration of key ecological processes on the seafloor. Though only 12 % of species assessed here were classed as threatened on the IUCN Red List, these species exhibited 1.8 times higher bioturbation scores than non-threatened species. 63 % of species assessed here have either not been evaluated or are data deficient and therefore have an unknown IUCN threat level. While these species have lower bioturbation impact scores on average than threatened species, their scores are higher than those of non-threatened ones. This means there may be several important bioturbators whose vulnerability to loss and extinction we are yet to discover. Further research exploring the impacts of decline and loss of populations of fish bioturbators would provide valuable insights into outcomes for ecosystem functioning.

We recognise that the effect of fish bioturbators, as with invertebrate bioturbators, will be dynamic and here we present a first approximation that we can build on. By providing a simple index to assess species’ per capita bioturbation impact, we are laying the groundwork for future work to investigate ecosystem-wide fish bioturbation impacts. Fish abundance is going to be important in mediating per capita bioturbation impact, with lower-ranked but numerous bioturbators having potentially larger population-level bioturbation impacts than higher-ranked but rare bioturbators. Our index presents a simple tool that can be applied to fish abundance data across different ecosystems to assess population and community-level bioturbation impacts. Previous work has explored how random and non-random extinction scenarios (ordered by stress sensitivity, body size, or rarity) affect invertebrate bioturbation (Solan et al., 2004), while similar research assessed the outcomes on fish nutrient cycling (McIntyre et al., 2007). These studies highlight some compensatory responses, with species with similar ecological roles replacing the contribution of lost species within the same functional group. Here, we show that many bioturbating families appear to have overlapping functional roles (Fig. 4), which suggests loss of these species may not result in a complete loss of assemblage functionality, highlighting the need to formally investigate the outcomes of different local extinction scenarios on the contributions of fish bioturbation to functioning.

Here we have shown that fish bioturbation is ubiquitous, encompasses a variety of groups and can be assessed using a simple index based on three ecological traits. We have highlighted the current research bias towards more charismatic species such as skates and rays and the need to extend this towards less glamorous but equally important bioturbators. In addition, a broader analysis bringing in local abundance data is required to determine which species dominate bioturbation at the population scale. With the increasing focus on processes that impact carbon fluxes at the ocean-benthic interface (Burrows et al., 2024; Epstein et al., 2022; Sala et al., 2021; Yahel et al., 2008), the need to include fish in this evidence base is important to ensure their substantial contribution to ecological processes of benthic biogeochemical cycles is recognised. Given that globally, marine sediments store significant amounts of organic carbon (Atwood et al., 2020; Burrows et al., 2024), better understanding the complex processes that shape carbon burial and storage on the seabed is crucial. Our findings provide new insights into the importance and ubiquity of fish bioturbation and provide the tools needed to assess how other factors may affect the contribution of fish to this crucial ecosystem service. Incorporating this information into management and protection decisions is key to promoting healthy and functioning benthic ecosystems.
